children: A 20-year-old woman undergoes an excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node.
A light microscopy view is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Hodgkin lymphoma. This diagnosis is established with a lymph node biopsy specimen showing Reed-Sternberg cells. These cells are large and are either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (“owl's eye” appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion–like nucleoli. Reed-Sternberg cells are usually derived from B lymphocytes. The absence of Reed–Sternberg cells has very high negative predictive value for Hodgkin disease.

objective.__html: Recognize a Reed-Sternberg cell to diagnose Hodgkin lymphoma.

children: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated for a lung nodule found during lung cancer screening.
PET/CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is lung cancer. The PET/CT scan shows enhanced uptake of the 18-fluorodeoxyglucose marker (seen as
red

on the image), indicating increased metabolic activity consistent with a high likelihood of malignancy. No abnormal 18-fluorodeoxyglucose uptake was seen elsewhere on the scan. Resection showed an adenocarcinoma with no evidence of spread to hilar or mediastinal nodes.

objective.__html: Diagnose lung cancer with PET/CT scan.

children: A 54-year-old man is evaluated for back pain and bilateral leg weakness.
An MRI of the spine is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is spinal cord compression caused by metastatic cancer. The MRI of the spine
shows
metastatic cancer with collapse of the vertebral body and compression of the spinal cord from the posteriorly displaced bony fragments (
arrow

objective.__html: Diagnose metastatic cancer spinal cord compression.

children: A 61-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue and anemia of 3 month's duration. Complete blood count shows pancytopenia. Splenomegaly is present.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hairy cell leukemia. The abnormal cell type seen on this peripheral blood smear is a hairy cell. Hairy cells are atypical lymphoid cells with cytoplasmic projections associated with hairy cell leukemia. This type of leukemia affects older and usually male patients and is characterized by splenomegaly, varying degrees of leukopenia (occasionally leukocytosis) or pancytopenia, and bone marrow infiltration.
A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for an eczematous patch on her left nipple that has been present for several months, as
shown
. The rash did not respond to topical glucocorticoids.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Paget disease of the breast is the most likely diagnosis. Paget disease of the breast consists of an erythematous, irregularly bordered plaque on the nipple-areolar complex, representing an extension of a ductal adenocarcinoma of the breast. Mammography may be normal. Diagnosis is established by skin biopsy.

objective.__html: Diagnose Paget disease of the breast.

title: Question 6

children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for fever, night sweats, and
neck swelling
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Hodgkin lymphoma. This patient has greatly enlarged cervical lymph nodes caused by Hodgkin lymphoma. Eighty to ninety percent of patients with Hodgkin lymphoma present with painless lymphadenopathy and may have B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss).

objective.__html: Diagnose Hodgkin lymphoma presenting as massive cervical lymphadenopathy.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 61-year-old man is evaluated for a lung nodule found incidentally on chest radiography.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is lung cancer. This patient's chest CT scan shows a 2-cm spiculated nodule. A nodule of this size with a spiculated border is highly likely to be malignant. Resection revealed a stage IA adenocarcinoma.

objective.__html: Diagnose lung cancer on CT scan.

children: A 54-year-old man is evaluated for a persistent and progressive pruritic skin condition of the trunk, arms, and palms, including both sun-exposed and sun-protected skin.
Representative findings on the posterior thorax are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is mycosis fungoides, a subtype of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The disease has various presentations; the most common presentation consists of persistent and/or progressive large, often pruritic, scaly patches or plaques that vary in size, shape, and color. Lesions occur on both sun-exposed and sun-protected skin. Diagnosis is made by skin biopsy.
A 49-year-old man is evaluated for cough and recent onset of hemoptysis.
Finger findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is lung cancer. Flattening of the normal angle between the base of the nail and the cuticle, as well as possible swelling of the distal digit, is called clubbing. Although seen in patients with lung cancer, it can also occur in other pulmonary conditions, such as bronchiectasis and tuberculosis, as well as cardiac and gastrointestinal conditions. This patient with clubbing, cough, and hemoptysis most likely has lung cancer.

objective.__html: Diagnose clubbing associated with lung cancer.

children: A 62-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated for an incidental finding of leukocytosis. Leukocyte count is 31,750/µL (31.75 × 10
/L) with 93% lymphocytes, 4% neutrophils, 2% monocytes, and 1% bands.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The key to diagnosis is the recognition of an increased blood leukocyte count resulting from increased numbers of mature lymphocytes and “smudge cells” on peripheral blood smear, as demonstrated in this image (
upper left of center
and
bottom left of center

), which are characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Smudge cells are caused by mature-appearing peripheral lymphocytes that are abnormally fragile and that become damaged during slide preparation.

title: Question 11

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for the painful breast changes
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is inflammatory breast cancer. Note that the patient's right breast has an inverted nipple, and the inferior portion of the breast is erythematous. These findings are characteristic of inflammatory breast cancer, accounting for approximately 3% of all breast cancers.

figureCredits: Image courtesy of the Inflammatory Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

children: A 22-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, weight loss, and exertional dyspnea.
Chest radiographs are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Hodgkin lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma represents approximately 10% of lymphomas and is curable in most, but not all, patients. Presentation with mediastinal, cervical, and supraclavicular involvement is particularly common for the nodular sclerosing subtype. Patients may also present with B symptoms, although that is more commonly seen in elderly patients with more advanced disease. The diagnosis is established with a lymph node biopsy specimen showing Reed-Sternberg cells, malignant cells that originate from germinal center B cells and are seen in an inflammatory infiltrate. This patient has an anterior mediastinal mass as
shown
that was diagnosed as Hodgkin lymphoma.

objective.__html: Diagnose Hodgkin lymphoma on chest radiography.

children: A 57-year old man is evaluated for right shoulder pain. Physical examination of the shoulder is normal.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is apical lung cancer, sometimes referred to as a Pancoast tumor or superior sulcus tumor. These tumors may present with shoulder pain, weakness and atrophy of the muscles of the hand, and Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis), caused by compression or involvement of C8, TI, and T2 nerve roots and the paravertebral sympathetic chain.
A 68-year-old man with a history of external beam radiation therapy for prostate cancer undergoes
colonoscopy
for evaluation of pelvic pain, diarrhea, mucus discharge, urgency, and tenesmus.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's colonoscopy findings are most consistent with radiation proctitis, likely resulting from his radiation treatment for prostate cancer. Although colonoscopy findings in patients with radiation proctitis may be nonspecific, the affected mucosa is frequently pale and friable, with extensive telangiectasia that may be a source of bleeding. In some patients, these colonoscopy findings may be less dramatic but still cause persistent bleeding. These changes are often in a segmental distribution, correlating with the region exposed to radiation, with an abrupt transition between injured and uninjured mucosa.

objective.__html: Identify characteristic colonoscopy findings of radiation proctitis.

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for an episode of gross hematuria with
cystoscopy
. He has a history of smoking.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is bladder cancer, the most common cancer of the genitourinary tract. Most patients have transitional cell carcinoma. This patient was diagnosed with a papillary transitional cell carcinoma. The most common presenting symptom is hematuria (often gross hematuria), which may be intermittent. It is typically painless, although irritative urinary symptoms may be present with or without hematuria. Any patient with gross hematuria should be referred for urologic evaluation, as should any patient confirmed to have persistent microscopic hematuria after evaluating benign causes, such as urinary tract infection, nephrolithiasis, or underlying kidney disease with a glomerular source of erythrocytes. Notably, use of anticoagulants does not alter these recommendations. The primary modality of initial evaluation is cystoscopy combined with urine cytology, with biopsy of any visible tumor or mucosal abnormality. Random biopsy is performed if no abnormality is seen.
A 56-year-old woman is evaluated for boring epigastric pain, jaundice, weight loss, and dyspnea. A contrast-enhanced
chest CT scan
is obtained to further evaluate abnormalities found on chest radiography.
Which of the following is the most likely pulmonary diagnosis?

This contrast-enhanced chest CT scan suggests metastatic carcinoma. There are multiple discrete nodular infiltrates of varying size scattered throughout the lungs. Although the differential diagnosis includes inflammatory and infectious causes, the appearance is consistent with metastatic cancer and is compatible with the patient's history. In this case, the diagnosis was metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

objective.__html: Recognize chest CT findings suggestive of metastatic cancer.
